prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: DCO+/DCN in IM Lup
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spatially resolve the DCO+, DCN, H2CO, D2CO, CO, 13CO and C18O emission toward the disk of IM Lup

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
High Data Rate: The number of spectral windows is primarily based on fulfilling the stated goals of imaging DCN, DCO+, H2CO, HDCO, CO, 13CO and C18O. The remaining windows have been placed on other lines likely to be detected in disks that will add to archival value of the data set. All window band widths are maximized to increase the chances of serendipitous detections, increasing the science output of the proposed observations.
Requested sensitivity: The sensitivity request is based on the expected flux of the weakest primary target line DCN. When detected in disks its integrated flux is ~200 mJy km/s. According to our simulations the emission is spread out over ~10 beams resulting in an integrated flux of 20 mJy km/s beam. To achieve a 5sigma detection in at least two channels across the 4 km/s lines (from Oberg et al. 2010, 2011) we request a rms of 2 mJy per 2km/s band width, which requires 20 min on source target. This sensitivity requirement was confirmed using the CASA SimObserve task; 20 min is the minimum integration time required to clearly detected the spatial distribution of DCN
Imaging requirements: To image the target molecules and resolve their distribution with respect to the disk temperature gradient and especially the 20 K midplane radius at ~0.25", we request a spatial resolution of 0.5". The largest spatial scales are ~ 6", which does not warrant the ACA. To confirm this we also compared simulated observations with the input model images and did not find any flux filtered out.
Correlator setup: Band 6 is optimal to image deuterated molecules in disks when considering both the intrinsic line strengths and the expected low excitation temperatures of these molecules -- the estimated excitation temperature of the deuterated molecules is below 30 K, based on astrochemical disk models. The frequency windows are selected to cover the 2-1, 3-2 or 4-3 lines of DCN, DCO+, H2CO, HDCO, CO, 13CO and C18O in a single spectral set-up. These primary lines are all observed with a high frequency resolution corresponding to ~0.17 km/s to enable detailed kinematic modeling, complementing the information from the spatial profile, for lines that are strong enough. For weaker lines, we will bin frequency channels to boost the SNR. For the lower priority lines we request a resolution of 0.3 km/s to barely resolve the lines while simultaneously obtaining continuum data.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spatially resolve the DCO+, DCN, H2CO, CO, 13CO and C18O emission toward the disk of HD 163296

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
High Data Rate: The number of spectral windows is primarily based on fulfilling the stated goals of imaging DCN, DCO+, H2CO, HDCO, CO, 13CO and C18O. The remaining windows have been placed on other lines likely to be detected in disks that will add to archival value of the data set. To achieve a 5sigma detection in at least two channels across the 4 km/s lines (from Oberg et al. 2010, 2011) we request a rms of 2 mJy per 2km/s band width, which requires 20 min on source target. This sensitivity requirement was confirmed using the CASA SimObserve task; 20 min is the minimum integration time required to clearly detected the spatial distribution of DCN

The frequency windows are selected to cover the 2-1, 3-2 or 4-3 lines of DCN, DCO+, H2CO, HDCO, CO, 13CO and C18O in a single spectral set-up. These primary lines are all observed with a high frequency resolution corresponding to ~0.17 km/s to enable detailed kinematic modeling, complementing the information from the spatial profile, for lines that are strong enough. prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H13CN/H13CO+ in IM Lup
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Spatially resolve H13CN, H13CO+, N2D+, and HDCO toward IM Lup. Additional windows are place on other interesting lines based on disk chemistry models.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
High Data Rate: The number of spectral windows is primarily based on fulfilling the primary goals of imaging H13CN, H13CO+, N2D+, and HDCO. The remaining windows have been placed on other lines likely to be detected in disks, e.g. HDO, CH3OH, that will add to archival value of the data set. All window band widths have been maximized to increase the chance of serendipitous line detections and thus the science output of the observations.
Requested sensitivity: The sensitivity request is based on the expected flux of the weakest primary target line HDCO. This line has yet to be detected in disks, but our model predicts an integrated flux of 20 mJy km/s beam. To achieve a 5sigma detection in at least two channels across the 4 km/s lines (from Oberg et al. 2010, 2011) we request a rms of 2 mJy per 2km/s band width, which requires 20 min on source target. This sensitivity requirement was confirmed using the CASA SimObserve task; 20 min is the minimum integration time required to clearly detect the spatial distribution of HDCO
Imaging requirements: To image the target molecules and resolve their distribution with respect to the disk temperature gradient and especially the 20 K midplane radius at ~0.25", we request a spatial resolution of 0.5". The largest spatial scales are ~ 6", which does not warrant the ACA. To confirm this we also compared simulated observations with the input model images and did not find any flux filtered out.
Correlator setup: Band 6 is optimal to image deuterated molecules in disks when considering both the intrinsic line strengths and the expected low excitation temperatures of these molecules -- the estimated excitation temperature of the deuterated molecules is below 30 K, based on astrochemical disk models. The frequency windows are selected to cover the 3-2 or 4-3 lines of H13CN, H13CO+, N2D+ and HDCO in a single spectral set-up. The lines are all observed with a high frequency resolution corresponding to ~0.15 km/s to enable detailed kinematic modeling, complementing the information from the spatial profile, for lines that are strong enough. For weaker lines, we will bin frequency channels to boost the SNR.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Protoplanetary disks links protostars and Solar System bodies physically and chemically. Deuterium fractionation is one of the most common tools to probe how these different stages are connected. Deuterium fractionation in molecules can for example be used to infer the importance of cold chemistry for different volatiles in the Solar System, including the Earth's sea water. The utility of deuterium fractionation as a probe is currently limited, however, by few, and seemingly contradictory observational constraints on the deuterium chemistry in disks; the spatially resolved fractionation pattern seems radically different both between molecules and between the two most well-studied disks, TW Hya and hD 163296. We propose to carry out a modest (6 source) survey of deuterium fractionation in disks that span a range of stellar and disk characteristics to explore (1), the variability in deuterium-enrichments during planet formation, and (2), the link between this variability and disk structures, ages, and impinging radiation fields. This would provide the strongest constraints to date on how the deuterium chemistry evolves between the protostellar stage and the mature Solar System.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Harvard College Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
